LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY
Borrower Independent State of Samoa
Project Description The economy of Samoa has been performing well in recent years.
Gross domestic product (GDP) growth accelerated from less than 1
percent in 1997 to 5.6 percent in 1999 and more than 7 percent in
2000. The good economic performance is attributed in part to the
successful  program  of  economic  and  financial  reform  and  good
governance that is boosting private sector activities.
The  power  supply  is  becoming  a  constraint  to  the  country's
economic and social development. The Project involves support to
the Government to deal with the constraint through policy changes,
institutional  capacity  building,  investments  in  power  supply
augmentation, and expansion of distribution networks as well as
environmental  improvement  and  social  services  for  the  affected
communities.
The events of 11 September 2001 are expected to slow down the
economic growth and electricity consumption in Samoa in the short
term. Thus, it becomes more important to substitute indigenous,
renewable,  and  cheaper  sources  of  energy  for  imported  oil
distillates. The substitution is also required to prepare the economy
for higher growth.
Classification Thematic: Economic growth
Environmental Category A. A summary environmental impact assessment (EIA)
Assessment was circulated to the Board on 19 July 2001.
Rationale The basic rationale of the Project lies in the need to improve the
capacity of the Electric Power Corporation (EPC) and increasingly
commercialize its operation to meet the growing power demand in
Samoa with the use of renewable resources and in a least-cost
manner.  The  Government's  energy  policy  aims  to  reduce
dependence on imported fuel by developing indigenous renewable
energy sources, and meeting the demand for electricity with a high
level  of  reliability.  The  proposed  Project  is  consistent  with  this
policy, as it will develop hydro energy resources in place of new
diesel-generated energy capacity. EPC's corporate plan stresses
the  aim  of  more  accountability,  transparency,  cost-effectiveness,
and  efficiency.  Technical  assistance  (TA)  will  be  provided  to
strengthen EPC's capability to reduce energy losses and operate
efficiently.
Objectives and Scope The main objective of the Project is to assist the Government and
EPC to undertake necessary policy changes, increase efficiency
and viability throughout the power sector, and undertake the highest
priority investment to augment the Afulilo hydropower scheme, in

I. THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan to the Independent State of Samoa for the Power Sector Improvement Project.1 The report
also describes proposed technical assistance for Strengthening Energy Loss Reduction and
Maintenance  Management  Capacity  of  the  Electric  Power  Corporation  (EPC),  and  if  the
proposed loan is approved by the Board, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the
Board, shall approve the technical assistance.
II. INTRODUCTION
2. Energy development is an important element of the Government strategy for economic
growth and social development in Samoa. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has provided
assistance  for  energy  sector  development,  the  power  subsector  in  particular,  since  1971.
Starting with the first technical assistance (TA) in 1971, ADB has provided 12 TAs and seven
loans for power sector development (para. 27). EPC was corporatized in 1972 in the course of
ADB's first power development loan to Samoa. Institutional strengthening and policy reforms,
tariff and revenue studies, commercialization and  improvement of the financial management of
the  EPC  have  been  important  areas  of  ADB  involvement,  with  the  long-term  objective  of
preparing the utility for eventual privatization.
3. ADB approved a loan for the Afulilo Hydroelectric Power Project in December 1986 for
the amount of $5.4 million.2 The project was cofinanced by the World Bank, European Union
(EU),  European  Investment  Bank  (EIB),  and  the  Australian  Agency  for  International
Development (AusAID). In April 1993, ADB approved supplementary financing3 to meet the
estimated cost overrun of SDR 1.457 million ($2.0 million equivalent at the time).4 The project
was successfully commissioned in June 1993. Its major objectives were met and, despite the
cost and time overruns in implementation, it was economically and financially viable.5
4. In  December  1994,  ADB  approved  a  TA  for  preparing  a  project  for  institutional
strengthening of EPC and increased electricity supply by augmenting Afulilo power. The South
Pacific  Regional  Environment  Programme  (SPREP)  prepared  a  preliminary  environmental
impact assessment (EIA) report, but the project could not proceed due to poor EPC financial
conditions that could not guarantee project sustainability. ADB financed another small-scale TA6
to update the project costs and the EIA in June 1999 when the policy dialogue was considered
back on track.
5. The proposed Project is designed to support the Government and EPC in undertaking
further policy reforms and capacity building to ensure that EPC continues to evolve toward full
private sector orientation, and in undertaking the highest priority investment of augmenting the
Afulilo power supply. The investment element of the Project is an integral part of the least-cost
development plan for the power sector, and receives highest priority from the Government. The

III. BACKGROUND
A. Sector Description
1.  Overview
6. The  energy  sector  in  Samoa  had  traditionally  been  dominated  by  consumption  of
indigenous biomass–wood fuel and coconut residues–for domestic cooking and crop drying. In
the 1990s, Samoa underwent a rapid transformation toward use of a commercial energy supply
based on imported petroleum and hydro-generated electricity. The transformation was driven
primarily by increasing demand for fossil fuel energy in transportation, including ground and sea
transportation, particularly fish transport. No hydrocarbon deposits have been found in Samoa.
Although a small geothermal resource has been located, it is too remote from population
centers to be utilized. The more expensive solar energy is limited to water heating and some
photovoltaic systems  on the smaller islands. Wind and wave energy are not a viable option due
to potential storm damage.
7. In 1989, biomass accounted for nearly 60 percent of primary energy supply, defined as
the gross energy available prior to any conversions. Diesel fuel and petrol accounted for 16 and
10  percent,  respectively,  and  hydroelectricity,  5  percent.  By  1998,  diesel  fuel  and  petrol
accounted for 22 and 17 percent of the primary energy supply respectively; hydroelectricity
increased to 7 percent, while biomass declined to less than 50 percent. A rapid increase in
demand for transportation, especially in 1997 and 1998, combined with increased requirements
for diesel power generation substantially raised the level of petroleum imports. It is expected
that the demand for diesel, petrol, and electricity in the next 10 years will further increase
relative to biomass. Transport-related fuels will account for 50 percent of the primary energy
supply  by  2008,  compared  with  34  percent  in  1989.8  As  demand  for  petroleum  products
continues to increase, the weight of petroleum external accounts is likely to rise in the medium
and long term, making the country vulnerable to the rapid price increases of petroleum products.
8. The trends of the primary energy supply are driven by the final energy consumption
pattern. Commercial energy consumption has grown substantially over the last 10 years while
the traditional or noncash energy consumption has declined. Transport recorded the biggest
share, increasing its final energy consumption from 28 percent in 1989 to 36 percent in 1998. In
the same period, the share of electricity increased from about 9 percent to 13 percent of total
energy consumption. Diesel was the primary fuel for generating electricity in that period.

2.  Power Demand
9. From 1989 to 1998, the domestic sector substantially increased its share of energy
consumption in the form of electricity, due to the Government’s program for rural electrification.
The 1997 Household Income and Expenditure Survey (HIES)9 indicated that 91 percent of the
households in Samoa used electricity for lighting, compared with less than 9 percent using gas
or  kerosene.  In  contrast,  only  2.6  percent  of  the  households  used  electricity  for  cooking.
Biomass dominated as a cooking fuel (74 percent). Even though it is cheaper than electricity for
cooking and easier to use than wood, propane gas use was only 8.3 percent.
10. The commercial sector represented the largest consumer group, accounting for 42.4
percent of the total electricity consumption in Samoa during 1991–2000. The domestic sector
was the second largest, representing 36 percent of consumption. The third largest group was
the religious and school facilities, accounting for 9.4 percent, followed by industry (7.2 percent),
hotels (3.5 percent), and streetlights (1.5 percent). A simple head count gave the total number
of electricity consumers in 2000 as 22,093. Of this, 92 percent were domestic consumers
(20,344 customers). Commercial consumers accounted for 4.5 percent (986 customers), with
hotels, industrial, religious and school facilities accounting for the remaining 3.5 percent.
11. Major power demand exists on the two main islands of Upolu and Savai'i. Upolu, where
the Afulilo hydropower scheme is located, had a peak demand of 13.5 megawatts (MW) in
2000, compared with the 2.5 MW peak demand in Savai'i. The demand on Manono Island was
less than 100 kilowatts (kW) and that on Apolima Island was less than 25 kW. The long-term
growth of the Upolu peak power demand has averaged 5.9 percent per annum, from 2.41 MW
in 1970 to 13.5 MW in 2000. The load demand increased at an annual rate of 5.4 percent
between 1991 and 2000. This trend is expected to continue, with the electricity demand in Upolu
to increase by an average of at least 4 percent a year in the next decade. Most of the growth is
anticipated to be in the commercial and domestic sectors (Appendix 2).
3.  Power Supply
12. EPC is responsible for providing power supply for the islands of Upolu, Savai'i, Manono,
and  Apolima.  The  Upolu  generation  system,  the  largest,  comprises  11.5  MW  installed
hydropower plants, and 12.8 MW installed diesel plants. The hydropower plants include the 4
MW Afulilo long-term storage hydropower plant, and four run-of-river (ROR) hydro stations. The
latter include a 1.0 MW (wet season capacity) station, a 1.6 MW station, a 1.4 MW station, and
a 3.5 MW station. The capacity of the ROR stations in the dry season is typically 80 percent less
than that in the wet season. Much of the 12.8 MW diesel plant is derated due to age and
mechanical restrictions and will be retired progressively in the near future. Also, due to the
reduced  hydropower  generation  capacity  in  the  dry  season,  except  for  the  Afulilo  storage
scheme, additional firm energy capacity is required in the Upolu power system. To summarize,
the Upolu system currently has a maximum generating capacity of 24.3 MW in the wet season
and 18.3 MW in the dry season. The firm capacity10 is only 10.3 MW, which is less than the 13.5
MW peak demand in 2000 (Appendix 3). Without additional generation capacity, the demand

4. EPC Organization and Power System
13. EPC was formed during ADB’s first power development loan to Samoa, which financed
new diesel capacity and extended the distribution network in Upolu and Savai'i. EPC was
established as a corporation under the Electric Power Corporation Act of 1972 and is wholly
owned by the Government. It is governed by a board chaired by the minister of works. Other
board members represent consumers, educational bodies, commercial  and religious groups,
and the EPC general manager. Prior to 1972, the power sector had been a department of public
works, which operated one small ROR hydropower station at Alaoa near Apia with a capacity of
1 MW in the wet season and 200 kW in the dry season, and another diesel station in Upolu.
14. In the last three decades, ADB has assisted EPC to supply the growing demand and to
become more efficient as well as more commercially oriented (para. 27). However, the full-scale
privatization of EPC is not on the Government agenda in the short and medium term. The main
reasons follow:
(i)  Privatization of electrical utilities in remote islands is not easy. Smallness of the
market, lack of skills, expensive logistics, need to supply rural areas, etc., are
real constraints to private sector investment.
(ii)  Power supply in Samoa is a monopoly. Before privatizing EPC, Samoa needs
additional regulatory reform–and a regulatory body–to define the tariff setup, as
well as establish clear and transparent rules for accountability. The regulatory
framework must also consider that electricity is pervasive and influences all other
sectors, and a minimum of electricity supply is a basic need.
(iii)  The policy objectives for the energy sector are to meet the growing demand by
maximizing the use of renewable indigenous resources, including hydropower,
and minimizing the import of fuel. These objectives are hard to achieve through
the  private  sector.  Renewable  energy  resources  are  characterized  by  high
investment costs and deferred returns.
(iv)  The Government–with ADB assistance–is implementing a privatization program.
Privatization has been part of the Government policy agenda since 1986, and
since  1986  ADB  has  been  assisting  the  Government  in  progressively
implementing  this  effort  in  a  logical  step-wise  fashion  (paras.  20-26).  EPC
privatization has not been identified as a priority.
(v)  Under current regulations, other entities are allowed to generate and distribute
power, under license from EPC. However, there is no such entity at present.
Firms and individuals may own and operate backup generators for their own use
when the public supply is not available. Ownership of backup generators by large
power consumers such as hotels is common.
15. The Upolu system combines transmission and distribution functions together as there
are no dedicated feeders to transfer power from generation centers to load centers. Power
distribution is by 33-kilovolt (kV), 22 kV, and 6.6 kV primary lines, and service is at 415/230

55
volts. The system is basically radial with the main load centers concentrated along the northern
coast–mainly around Apia, the capital–and the western part of the island.
16. There are two main generation centers. One is located at the load center in Apia and
based on diesel as well as ROR hydropower generation. The second generation center is
located in the northeast of the island where there are significant hydropower resources including
the Afulilo hydroelectric power scheme and Lalomunga scheme. These two generation centers
are connected with a radial single circuit 33 kV distribution feeder (north coast feeder). The
feeder is 32 kilometers (km) long and connects the switchyards at Lalomunga (northeast) and
Tanugamanono (Apia). The 33 kV feeder does not have a 33 kV switchgear and relies on a 22
kV switchgear with the possibility of exceeding the capacity of the equipment in the peak
periods. The feeder also supplies some load (in Solosolo) along the north coast. The feeder is
connected to the 22 kV distribution by 6 megavolt-ampere (MVA) auto-transformers.
17. In addition to the north coast transmission line, there is a south coast transmission loop
that follows the Cross Island Road and South Coast Road to connect the northeast generation
center  (Afulilo  hydropower)  to  the  north  coast  load  center.  This  22  kV  transmission  line
connecting generation and load centers is radial and therefore vulnerable to load disturbances.
Any outage of the radial transmission line connecting the Afulilo power scheme to the load
center has the potential to totally black out the system. The capacity of the south transmission
loop needs to be upgraded to allow transmission of the increased power output from the
proposed Project to the major load center in Apia.
18. Under the rural electrification program started in the early 1990s, EPC built distribution
extensions to rural villages extensively. By the end of 2000, EPC had provided access to
electricity  for  approximately  94  percent  of  Samoa’s  population.  After  these  projects  were
completed, the Government reimbursed the initial costs of the rural electrification projects to
EPC. EPC is responsible for the operation and maintenance (O&M) of the rural electrification
projects.
19. The  energy  losses,  defined  as  the  percentage  difference  between  gross  energy
generated and energy sold, were 15.2 percent in FY1994/95, 18.8 percent in FY1995/96, 17.1
percent in FY1997/98, 16.0 percent in FY1998/99, and 15 percent in FY1999/2000. These loss
percentages are high. A number of technical and nontechnical factors contribute to the high
losses  in  EPC’s  system.  A  1998  tariff  study  recommended  that  12  percent  would  be  an
appropriate target for EPC to reduce its energy loss.
B. Government Policies and Plans
1. Overview
20. The Government has continued its program of economic and financial reforms aimed at
strengthening the economic base of the country. It has liberalized and reformed the financial
sector to facilitate private investment. This is consistent with ADB's own Pacific strategy,11 which
emphasizes the need to remove impediments to private sector growth as a priority in countries
relatively well-endowed with natural resources such as Samoa. The benefits of this reform are
now reflected in the country's economic performance. From a low of 1 percent in 1997, growth
in the economy (GDP) accelerated to 3.4 percent in 1998 and 5.6 percent in 1999. In 2000,

behind  the  strong  performance,  with  commerce,  transport,  communications,  finance,  and

21. Over the past few years, Samoa has refocused its reform policies on promoting private
sector  development  and  reducing  the  dominance  of  the  public  sector.  Good  progress  in
introducing modern public-sector management practices has been made in a relatively short
period  and  the  public  sector  has  become  more  accountable  and  transparent.  Other
achievements include wide-ranging financial sector reforms, specifically triggered by ADB’s
Financial  Sector  Program  Loan  (FSPL),12  and  substantial  improvements  to  an  enabling
business environment.
22. With a remaining portfolio of 28 state-owned enterprises (SOEs), including EPC, the
public sector still accounts for a large part of the country’s economic activities and formal
employment. Inadequate standards of oversight in the past have tended to exempt SOEs from
public scrutiny, which has led to a low degree of corporate governance and performance. To
strengthen the legal and institutional framework for enhanced performance and governance of
SOEs,  and  as  required  under  the  FSPL,  the  Government  introduced  the  Public  Bodies
(Performance and Accountability) Bill 2001 in Parliament to provide the umbrella legislative
framework for SOEs (or Public Bodies).13 This Bill, in combination with the Companies Act 2001
and Public Finance Management Act 2001, constitutes a significantly improved framework for
SOE reporting and monitoring, and is expected to lead to enhanced SOE performance and
corporate governance.
23. The  introduction  of  the  new  legislative  framework  represents  an  important  step  to
improve the enabling business environment for the private sector, and substantially enhance
SOE performance and corporate governance. The Government acquired a new momentum to
carry forward the reform process in terms of commercialization and privatization.  ADB has
assisted the implementation of the privatization strategy14 and is considering further assistance
to  implement  the  SOE  reform  strategy  by  (i)  implementing  the  reporting,  monitoring,  and
advisory provisions of the new SOE legislation, including the Companies Act 2001, the Public
Finance Management Act 2001 and the Public Bodies (Performance and Accountability) Bill
2001; (ii) undertaking action to privatize SOEs in accordance with the Government’s reform
priorities; (iii) supporting the Government in formulating objectives and strategies for the SOEs
that it plans to retain over the medium term; (iv) strengthening the capacity of the Government
to implement SOE reforms, and (v) addressing other management and governance issues in
SOEs.

sector-led economic growth. The country's energy policy aims to reduce national spending on
the  importation  of  petroleum  products.  Emphasis  is  on  (i)  employing  indigenous  energy
resources  in  place  of  imports,  whenever  economically  feasible;  (ii)  promoting  energy

D. Lessons Learned
29. ADB has extensive experience in the power sector in the Asian and Pacific region. The
major lessons from this experience were evaluated in 1997.16 The evaluation concluded that the
factors crucial to successful project performance have been (i) experience and capability of the
executing agency; (ii) appropriateness of technical design; (iii) timely and adequate availability
of counterpart funding; (iv) reliability of demand and load forecasts; (v) flexible ADB intervention
and increased supervision throughout the project cycle; (vi) adoption of geological, hydrological,
and environmental impact investigations and abatement measures; (vii) effective application of
O&M  standards  and  procedures;  and  (viii)  determined  implementation  of  cost  recovery
mechanisms and tariff reforms. It was noted that close periodic monitoring of major project risks
and  assumptions,  notably  demand  forecasts,  generating  capacity,  system  losses,  fuel  and
electricity  pricing,  geological  and  climatological  (e.g.,  rainfall)  conditions,  and  the  security
situation would improve project administration and facilitate economic and financial evaluation of
projects at completion and postevaluation.
30. The overall rating of completed and postevaluated projects in the power sector indicated
that  79  percent  of  the  projects  were  generally  successful,  with  only  1  percent  rated  as
unsuccessful.  A  number  of  project  objectives  had  been  substantially  met,  including  the
following:  (i)  expanding,  rehabilitating  or  upgrading  power  generation  to  meet  the  growing
demand for electricity; (ii) reducing dependence on imported sources by developing indigenous
sources  of  energy;  (iii)  improving  overall  power  systems  reliability  and  efficiency;  and  (iv)
improving access of the poor to power. Sustaining success in the sector requires increased
emphasis on (i) critically assessing energy demand to avoid underutilization or overcapacity of
power supply; (ii) incorporating appropriate cost recovery and energy efficiency mechanisms on
both supply and demand sides; (iii) ensuring proper O&M of project facilities; (iv) considering
environmental factors in energy development; and (v) improving the institutional capacity of
energy  entities  in  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  as  executing  and  implementing
agencies, with a view to redefining the role of the government and enlarging the scope for
private sector participation in the subsector.
31. Another impact evaluation study of ADB assistance to the power sector was specific  to
the  Pacific  DMCs,  including  Samoa.17  The  1998  study  report  concluded  that  institutional
strength, not capital finance, is the principal constraint facing the Pacific DMC power sector.
Therefore, technical assistance to the power sector in the Pacific DMCs should be emphasized
and should promote: (i) improved O&M, (ii) improved standards of safety and environmental
protection, (iii) increased efficiency and lower costs, (iv) increased management capacity for
both  administration  and  planning,  (v)  improved  reporting  and  increased  transparency  of
operations,  and  (vi)  improved  measurement  of  performance.  These  dimensions  were  all
carefully considered in designing this Project.

C. Technical Justification
65. The  existing  Afulilo  hydropower  scheme  provides  a  total  capacity  of  4  MW  and  a
maximum power supply of 24 gigawatt-hours (GWh) per annum. The dam is made of concrete
with a central spillway, wings, and rockfill abutment on both sides. The existing reservoir surface
area is approximately 251 hectares (ha). It will be increased by 7.8 percent to 270.4 ha. The
hydraulic discharge is conveyed through an intake tunnel 60 m long below the left abutment.
This tunnel is then connected to a 4.0 km long descending penstock that carries the hydraulic
discharge to the powerhouse in Ta’elefaga village near Fagaloa Bay.
66. The existing Afulilo scheme was designed and constructed with provision for expansion.
The  Project  is  needed  now  to  cope  with  the  increasing  power  demand  and  deteriorating
reliability of the system, particularly during the dry season. The Project will augment the existing
Afulilo  power  by  installing  an  additional  2  MW  generating  unit.  This  will  be  relatively
straightforward as the size of the existing penstock is adequate for the increased water flow and
the civil works at the power station were already built for the installation of a third generator.
67. Extra water to power the third generator was previously envisaged to come from the
construction of the Vaipu pumping station immediately downstream of Afulilo. In view of the
considerable environmental concern about flooding of the Vaipu swamp, the Vaipu station could
not be developed. On the other hand, seepage through the floor of the Afulilo reservoir is much
smaller than envisaged. The Afulilo dam feasibility study revealed more than 5 m of lake
sediments in the basin upstream of the dam. These sediments help reduce seepage. Thus,
raising the reservoir/dam spillway and constructing a canal outside the present catchment to
increase the water flow of the reservoir can justify the addition of a third generator in Afulilo’s

1188
powerhouse. The revision of the hydrology of the catchment areas was originally carried out in
TA 2267,26 and reconfirmed by TA 3203 (footnote 6).
68. Construction of the Afulilo hydroelectric power project began in 1991. In March 1993 the
dam was closed and the storage began filling. The first runs of the two generators were carried
out in July and August 1993. By August the reservoir had reached 316.40 m above sea level
(masl) (1.1 m below the 317.50 masl full supply level) and the scheme was regularly supplying
power to the grid. The storage continued to fill and the reservoir began to spill in October 1993
and  continued  to  spill  until  late  November  1993.  The  reservoir  spilled  intermittently  from
November 1993 to March 1994. The last spill took place in January 1997. Since then, EPC has
managed to prevent water spills and to maximize the power output from the Afulilo scheme.
69. The Afulilo power augmentation will increase the height of the dam by 1.7 m from 317.50
masl to 319.20 masl. It will increase the reservoir’s gross storage volume from 10 million m3 to
15 million m3. The key objective is to store the water in the wet season and use it to produce
power in the dry season. With the augmented installed capacity of 2 MW and the average
augmented generation from 21 to 31 GWh per annum, the plant capacity factor (percent of the
time plant is  running) will be reduced from 0.60 to 0.58, which reflects better its peaking
capacity. During the wet season from November to March when other ROR hydropower units
are running, the augmented Afulilo scheme will be run only a few hours a day during daytime
and system evening peak periods (from 6:30 pm to 9:30 pm). The Project will be operated at full
capacity during most of the day in the dry season (from April to October) when other ROR
hydropower units are not running.

V. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION
A. Economic and Financial Analyses
92. This section presents the economic and financial analyses of the investment being
financed under the loan for the Power Sector Improvement Project. The financial projections for
EPC and power tariffs are discussed in Chapter III and Appendix 7. Further details are available
on request.
93. The economic and financial analyses of the project investment for Afulilo augmentation
compared the benefits of the additional power generation to the total cost. In addition, a least-
cost economic analysis was conducted to demonstrate that augmentation is less expensive than
an alternative diesel power generation. The switching values related to the parameters used in
the analysis were also computed (Appendix 14).
94. The economic cost estimates are based on May 2001 prices and include base costs,
costs of the environmental and social mitigation measures described earlier (paras. 82-89), and
physical contingencies, but no taxes and duties. The economic benefits were calculated by
multiplying the forecast net additional power generation by the present value of the weighted
resource cost savings of consumer alternative sources of energy, and consumers' willingness to
pay. The average tariff was used as a proxy for the willingness of the consumers to pay for the
electricity.
95. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the base case is estimated to be 22.0
percent. Thus, the project proposal is economically justifiable. Based on the net present value
(NPV) of total economic cost, the project proposal is also less expensive than the diesel
generation alternative. At a discount rate of 12 percent, the NPV of the economic cost is $5.40
million, while the NPV of the diesel alternative’s cost is $8.62 million.
96. The Project is fully consistent with the Government’s strategy for emphasizing renewable
power development and reducing fuel imports. Sensitivity analysis was carried out to test the
robustness of the results to standard changes in the underlying assumptions (Table 8). The
switching points would be if (i) benefits were 47 percent lower (equivalent to 5.3 GWh per year),

(ii)  costs  were  85  percent  higher,  or  (iii)  there  would  be  more  than  five  years  delay  in
implementation. The Project remains viable in all cases.
97. For the financial analysis, financial costs used  include the economic costs and duties
and taxes. The financial analysis was performed by comparing the financial cost with the
benefits  of  the  additional  power  generation.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  is
estimated to be 18 percent. The Project is financially justifiable. The FIRR also remains robust
for the sensitivity scenarios, as shown in Table 8.

B. Environment
100. The Project will help EPC reduce air pollutants and greenhouse gas emissions that
would result from a diesel power generation alternative. The potential environmental impacts will
be minimized through various mitigation measures as an integrated part of the Project. EPC will
strengthen its capability by adding new staff with environmental management training to be
responsible for implementing the mitigation measures identified in the EIA report. EPC will
provide  an  annual  budget  for  carrying  out  the  environmental  management  and  monitoring
program  to  address  any  unforeseen  environmental  issues  after  project  completion.  The
strengthened environmental management capability at EPC will help ensure the sustainable use
of renewable hydropower.

2277
C. Social Dimensions
101. The Project will generate net social benefits. It will create 40-60 unskilled and semiskilled
new jobs and wage income mainly for local villagers during construction. As noted before, the
new  water  supply  system  that  SWA/EPC  will  build  as  part  of  this  Project  will  provide  a
convenient water supply and prevent the risks and costs of taking water from the stream,
particularly for children and women in Ti'avea village. Additionally, the Project will build a new
bridge to improve the safety of the bridge crossing for Ta’elefaga villagers, especially children
and women. The new lifeline rate that EPC will implement will make electricity rate 17 percent
less than the current electricity tariff for poor consumers, (approximately 9,560 consumers, or 47
percent of EPC’s total number of domestic customers). The Project will substantially improve
the power system's reliability, particularly in the dry season. The improved reliability will benefit
villagers the most as they will encounter less frequent power outages. At present, the rural
areas encounter more power outages than do urban areas. Power outages disrupt the health
care provided by clinics and hospitals and activities of schools in the villages. More reliable
electricity service will reduce the need for villagers to use other fuels for lighting. Alternative
fuels such as kerosene and alcohol are more expensive and dangerous, while wood fuels
generate pollution and lead to more tree cutting in the forest.

A. Background
1. Upgrading of the Upolu Power System was studied under TA 2267-SAM,1 and the
results are presented in the Final Report, Volume 2-Power Development Plan and Volume 3-
Technical Appendixes dated October 1997. The study investigated a number of development
options for increasing the system's generating capacity to cope with the expected load growth
and dry season demand and improvement of the transmission system's reliability. The study
concluded that the least-cost generation development plan is to augment the output from Afulilo
hydropower station.
2. The recommended works for augmenting the output from Afulilo/Ta’elefaga hydropower
station (the Project) include (i) constructing the 7.1-kilometer (km) eastern diversion channel to
increase  the  water  flowing  into  Afulilo  reservoir,  (ii)  raising  the  Afulilo  dam  1.7  meters  to
increase the regulating capacity of the reservoir, (iii) installing a third 2-megawatt generating set
in the Ta’elefaga power station, (iv) upgrading the south coast transmission loop from 22
kilovolts (kV) to 33 kV; (v) upgrading transformer capacity of the north coast transmission loop
from 6 megavolt-amperes (MVA) to 12 MVA; and (vi) upgrading the Afulilo telemetry equipment.
These improvements–found to be technically and economically viable with only minor adverse
environmental and social impacts–were recommended for implementation.
3. To carry out these works, the Electric Power Corporation (EPC) will require the services
of an international consulting firm experienced in engineering such works. The consultancy will
involve three major stages, namely: review and detailed design, tender and award of contract,
and supervision and construction.
1. Review and Detailed Design (Stage 1)
(i)  Review the technical, environmental and social impacts, and the economics of
the capital work items (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v), and (vi) in para. 2.
(ii)  Carry out additional investigations including detailed topographic survey, and
geotechnical investigations for capital work items (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v), and (vi).
(iii)  Check the stability and load flow characteristics of the existing power system with
the addition of the third 2-MW generator [items (iii) and (iv)] and recommend
modifications if necessary.
(iv)  Check  lightning  protection  for  the  existing  two  hydro-generating  sets  in
Ta’elefaga Power Station and recommend modifications if necessary.
(v)  Prepare detailed design, drawings, schedule of quantities, and cost estimates of
all capital works items (i) to (vi) in para. 1 and modifications identified under items
(iii) and (iv), Stage 1.

A.  Introduction
1. The financial and economic analyses of the Project examined the benefits of additional

economic analysis was conducted to demonstrate that the Project is less expensive than the

B.  Methodologies
2. In the economic and financial analyses, the benefits of the Project are estimated based
on the additional power generation throughout the project life. All the costs are expressed in
2001 terms. The financial benefits were computed by multiplying the forecast net generation
(after adjustment of energy loss) by the average system tariff  in present value of cents per
kilowatt-hour (kWh) in each year of the project life. The current average electric tariffs are used
in evaluating the financial benefits.
3. The  Project  is  designed  to  meet  a  combination  of  nonincremental  and  incremental
demand. The economic benefits were calculated based on a per-unit weighted average of the

current average tariff was used as a proxy for the consumers' willingness to pay for electricity.1

sources of energy. For this estimation, the assumptions used follow: (i) domestic and small
commercial customers account for approximately 60 percent of the Electric Power Corporation
